text: Can I just check, for those of you paying premium charge. Am I right that it has the potential to make profitable punting/value betting strategies unprofitable? More likely with higher hit rate strategies from what I can tell. Also presumably if you market make alongside value betting then (assuming the market making hit rate is very high) you could make a lot of value betting strategies unprofitable also?

elements.text: Can I just check, for those of you paying premium charge. Am I right that it has the potential to make profitable punting/value betting strategies unprofitable? More likely with higher hit rate strategies from what I can tell. Also presumably if you market make alongside value betting then (assuming the market making hit rate is very high) you could make a lot of value betting strategies unprofitable also?

text: No

elements.text: No

text: Assuming by “profitable” you mean net profitable i.e. after commission but before PC

elements.text: Assuming by “profitable” you mean net profitable i.e. after commission but before PC

text: In fact if you already have profitable strategies you are paying PC on then it turns gross break even i.e. net negative strategies into positive ones once you account for the impact it has on your PC position

elements.text: In fact if you already have profitable strategies you are paying PC on then it turns gross break even i.e. net negative strategies into positive ones once you account for the impact it has on your PC position

text: You can also view having to pay PC as receiving an R&D credit on your losses of strategies under development

elements.text: You can also view having to pay PC as receiving an R&D credit on your losses of strategies under development

text:
Thanks Mo, yes that would be my definition of profitable. I thought though that if my lifetime comms generated weren't X% of my lifetime profits (X being 20% or 40% depending on the band) I would incur PC on winnings each week until they hit that band.

I can see a scenario there where say you win 1 in 10 bets but are below the life time comms level you are then charged PC on the winning bet which effectively brings your commission paid on that bet to well over 5%.  If the net gain from winning bets as part of a strategy is much lower but you are still losing the same amount on the losing bets in the sequence then it can turn a strategy unprofitable no?

elements.text:
Thanks Mo, yes that would be my definition of profitable. I thought though that if my lifetime comms generated weren't X% of my lifetime profits (X being 20% or 40% depending on the band) I would incur PC on winnings each week until they hit that band.

I can see a scenario there where say you win 1 in 10 bets but are below the life time comms level you are then charged PC on the winning bet which effectively brings your commission paid on that bet to well over 5%.  If the net gain from winning bets as part of a strategy is much lower but you are still losing the same amount on the losing bets in the sequence then it can turn a strategy unprofitable no?

text: You don’t get charged PC on the “winning bet”. You get charged PC on you aggregate weekly winnings, and nothing if you had a loss for the week

elements.text: You don’t get charged PC on the “winning bet”
You get charged PC on you aggregate weekly winnings, and nothing if you had a loss for the week

text: How close are you to the lifetime allowance?

elements.text: How close are you to the lifetime allowance?

text:
Thanks Mo. I know its on the aggregate weekly winnings but assume these consist solely of the winning bet and nothing else. Then it effectively increases the coms you pay on the winnings of that bet without taking into account that bet was the only 1 in 10 you won, and assume the 9 losses were the previous week/s. As you are now netting less on your winning bets than you were before PC was applied your strategy may now be a losing strategy as the winners don't cover the losses.

I can see how this may still be a strategy that you may want to run, if running other profitable high hit rate strategies that don't generate much coms,  as it generates coms that compensate for those strategies. But still there is the possibility that if you had _*only*_ that one strategy, as described above ,you could find it becomes unprofitable once you hit PC. Unless I have misunderstood something.

I am no where near the lifetime allowence yet. I will have a deficit to work through too. I am just planning ahead and trying to figure out what to concentrate on next.

text: Eh? Your aggregate weekly winnings are the sum of your winning bets and your losing bets

elements.text: Eh? Your aggregate weekly winnings are the sum of your winning bets and your losing bets

text: Assume you win 1 in 10 bets and you are winning that one in a week where you place no other bets (the losses occurred in previous weeks) so have no losses that week. Your aggregate weekly winnings would be the winnings from that one bet in this case.

elements.text: Assume you win 1 in 10 bets and you are winning that one in a week where you place no other bets (the losses occurred in previous weeks) so have no losses that week. Your aggregate weekly winnings would be the winnings from that one bet in this case.

text:
I've often wondered what I think Trex is getting it. For me it is hypothetical right now, but let's say I pay 20% PC, in general. Next week I lose £5k, but week after I make £15k. I am £10k over the 2 weeks in the green but I get charged £3k on that +15 week and 0 on the negative week, My average profit is £10k and my rate is 20% so by that non-uniformity of profit I have paid an extra £1k compared with what I would have on an average profit of £5k per week?
Is this too simplistic or is it just the reality of non-uniformity of profits?

elements.text:
I've often wondered what I think Trex is getting it. For me it is hypothetical right now, but let's say I pay 20% PC, in general. Next week I lose £5k, but week after I make £15k. I am £10k over the 2 weeks in the green but I get charged £3k on that +15 week and 0 on the negative week, My average profit is £10k and my rate is 20% so by that non-uniformity of profit I have paid an extra £1k compared with what I would have on an average profit of £5k per week?
Is this too simplistic or is it just the reality of non-uniformity of profits?

text:
You don't get charged £3k on the +15 week because you started that week greater than 20% commission rate

You started the £5k losing week on 20% then you lost £5k so your rate was higher

text:
1. What is your lifetime gross profit
2. What is your lifetime commission plus PC
3. If 2. / 1. is less than 20%, charge you whatever amount required to top you up to 20%

What is your lifetime commission plus PC
If 2. / 1. is less than 20%, charge you whatever amount required to top you up to 20%

text:
Regarding the `<http://trading.in|trading.in>_play_service`, specifically regarding the elapsed time of the *soccer* games:
Let's say we currently have a return of 10 minutes and 25 seconds (`10:25`) of the match
If we collect data every 1 second, we will see this sequence:

`[10:25, 10:25, 10:25, 10:25, 11:50, 11:50, 10:25, 10:25, 11:50, 11:50]`

There is not actually a real-time update (second by second). Have any of you ever thought of a parallel way to properly mark minute by minute or second by second of the games in a more reliable way?

If so, and if you could share the idea, I would greatly appreciate it, as I am trying to work with this timing requirement, and there is no affordable ($$$) livescore API for personal use that covers all games on the Betfair Exchange.

If so, and if you could share the idea, I would greatly appreciate it, as I am trying to work with this timing requirement, and there is no affordable ($$$) livescore API for personal use that covers all games on the Betfair Exchange.

text:
I had even started a method using the `open_date` in games that pass through the `in_play_only=True` filter (It's useful because the last `open_date` saved record is exactly the moment the ball started rolling in the game), and when the `_datetime_created - open_date` was greater than `45:00`, we would be in additional time, and when the `Half Time` market closed, that would mean the first half was end.

However, this way I would not be able to know when the second half started, limiting it to only the first half. ((And this method has several flaws in it, it was just an attempt to find an option))

text: I've noticed from manual recreational bet placement that for certain football matches, the inplay delay is reduced a lot while a game is in half time break (about 1 second). I pretty much only bet on prem games so no idea about other leagues. Not sure why this is nor how consistent it is but it might be something to help you identify the beginning of second half.

text:
Thanks Mo. I went over the maths of it and yea I see that actually even in the scenario I posed you can't actually turn the strategy into a losing one because of the coms like you said. That wasn't immediately apparent to me.

Tried another scenario where I made the hit rate 50% too with a loss in one week and a win the next. Even though the coms weren't at X% the PC applied to the winning bet still left the strategy in profit. So I guess the maths behind PC was designed with all this in mind.
